columns.text: **11.3a** As part of this question, we are asked to explain how fixed costs are comparable to sunk costs.

**Fixed costs** and **sunk costs** are both expenses that are incurred but cannot be recovered. Sunk costs are expenses that have already been paid for and cannot be recovered, regardless of the quantity of items produced. For example, if a corporation buys five-year-old equipment but only uses it for three months, the equipment has a fixed cost of $3,000. The corporation will have invested $3,000 in the equipment even if it is not used. Regardless, the expense is unjustifiable.

**11.3b** In this part of the question, we've been asked to define the net income related to the accounting break-even point and to consider the tax implications in order for the net income to be zero at the accounting break-even point.

This is because the break-even point is the point at which total revenues are equal to total costs. Since income taxes are a cost, at the break-even point, there would be no income to tax. So, if total costs exceed total revenues, then a net loss results. In this case, the company would need to either reduce costs or increase revenues to break even. Conversely, if total costs are less than total revenues, then net income will be positive. This is because the difference between total costs and total revenues is considered a profit. Finally, when total costs are greater than total revenues, then a net loss results, and the company would need to reduce costs or increase revenue to return to breakeven.Â
**11.3c** In this part of the question we are being asked to explain why the finance manager is interested in the accounting break even point.

The **accounting break-even point** is when a company's expenses and revenue are equal. The accounting break-even point may be of interest to financial management since it can assist a company in determining how much money it should spend and how much money it should bring in. If a company's expenses exceed its revenue, it may need to make adjustments to its operations. If a company's expenses are less than its revenue, it may be able to continue operating at a loss while making more investments in the firm.

**a.** For this, we first need to define the two. 

**Fixed costs** are the operational expenses that can no longer be changed. These include taxes, rent, salary, etc. On the other hand, **sunk costs** are the costs incurred by the firm in the past. These includes all the costs including their fixed costs. 

The main similarity of these two is that they can be disregarded in decision making since fixed costs are constant and sunk costs no longer have an impact on the current situation.

**b.** During accounting breakeven, the net profit is zero. This means that the profit and the costs are equal to each other. When this happens, there is nothing to be taxed, therefore the tax is also zero in this situation.

**c.** Accounting break-even allows the manager to identify the amount that a project should earn to negate the losses/cost of operation. With this, they can plan out other strategies to help increase their earnings. Additionally, it will help the manager assess if there can be improvements in terms of costing and investing to make the project more profitable.
